column4: I don't use Ubuntu, but my question could be applicable to Ubuntu if I choose to use it.  I current have a HD install of KNOPPIX, and my drive died.  I got a new drive (for now, it's a totally diff size and geometry), and moved my files onto it.  All the files copied, and now when I run "grub-install", I never get a working bootloader.  I've even dd'ed my old 446byte grub into the mbr manually, and all I get is a "cha cha cha cha cha"
out of the floppy drive, even though it can't be the BIOS booting the floppy, and grub does not have a floppy config.   Could it be my stage1/stge2 that I havwe to delete to get them regerneated?
did you take care to make exact copies of the device files etc.?
confusing that it should try to access the floppy.
from what context did you run grub-install?
it was chroot /mnt/hda1 grub-install /dev/hda (from a KNOPPIX offline environment)
the command has worked flawlessly numerous times before.
with /boot/grub/ in place in /mnt/hda1 I assume?
I know what I would do.
get the new install booted somehow, perhaps with Super Grub Disk or a tool like that. Then run grub-install from there.
is super grub disk more than just a simple linux bootcd with grub?  It would be nice to have something smarter or more helpful.
I haven't used it myself, but once you manage to boot grub (any grub, could even be a floppy one), you can do 'find', 'geometry', 'kernel', 'boot' etc from the command line.
this super grub disk looks interesting, I will try it out right away.
if I was using Ubuntu, and I moved my system to a new drive, does the ubuntu livecd have a tool to fix my mbr?
yes, and there is a set of instructions to do it (because Windows installation routinely messes up grub)
